Chapter on Discrimination, Part 2, Question:
What is meant by knowing dharmas, cognizing dharmas, and illuminating dharmas?
Answer:
The knower is all dharmas, the cognizer and illuminator are also so,
The knower, mental consciousness, and illuminator, each is explained according to its function.
The knowledge of suffering knows suffering, up to the knowledge of the path knowing the path, because the impure knowledge has conditioned objects.
The knowledge of good and so forth also knows suffering, up to space, the number of non-obstructions, and the number of obstructions, because it universally takes all dharmas as objects.
The cognizer also cognizes all dharmas, the eye consciousness cognizes form, up to the body consciousness cognizing touch, because it includes its own characteristics.
The mental consciousness cognizes the eye, form, and eye consciousness, and so on, because it universally takes all as objects.
The illuminator also illuminates all dharmas according to their functions.
The knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the path illuminate suffering and the path, because they take conditioned phenomena as their objects.
Good contaminated wisdom also illuminates suffering up to space and non-analytical cessation.
Question:
How does an eon pass?
Answer:
It is said that the passing of a medium eon is due to the sword, disease, and famine,
And the passing of a great eon is due to the three except for the earth.
It is said that the passing of a medium eon is due to the sword, disease, and famine. The passing of a medium eon is of three kinds: sword, disease, and famine.

The sword eon is when the lifespan of humans is ten years, they are greedy for coarse and evil objects, practice various wrong dharmas, each harboring a mind to harm, holding grass and trees in their hands all become swords and knives, and they kill each other.
In this way, for seven days, the sword eon passes.

As for the pestilence kalpa, it also occurs when the lifespan is ten years. There are many illnesses, no physicians, prescriptions, or nurses. Due to meager blessings and virtues, one dies upon encountering an illness.
Thus, after seven months and seven days, the pestilence kalpa passes.

As for the famine kalpa, it also occurs when the lifespan is ten years. Hunger and thirst increase, the body becomes extremely weak and emaciated. There is a severe drought everywhere, crops do not grow, and people eat rice grains. They boil human bones to drink the broth.
Thus, after seven years, seven months, and seven days, the famine kalpa passes.
Those who say this way, if one observes the precept of not killing for one day and one night in this world, one will never be born in the midst of the weapon kalpa.
If one offers a harÄ«takÄ« fruit to the Sangha's field of blessings, one will never be born in the midst of the pestilence kalpa.
If one offers a meal to the Sangha's field of blessings, one will never be born in the midst of the famine kalpa.
The evil kalpas arise in this JambudvÄ«pa, but in other places they are less similar.
In this world, when the kalpa of warfare arises, there is only an increase in anger there.ğŸ”½In this world, when the kalpa of pestilence arises, there is only weakness and little strength there.
In this world, when the kalpa of famine arises, there is only an increase in hunger and thirst there.
Question:
How does a great kalpa pass?
Answer:
Except for the earth, the other three kinds are called the passing of a great kalpa.
The three great elements are said to pass through a great kalpa, namely fire, water, and wind, not the earth element.
Why is it so?
Because it is not beneficial.
The beneficial one destroys the great kalpa.
Moreover, as for the destruction of the earth element, the destruction should reach the fourth dhyÄna, but it has never reached the fourth dhyÄna.
Question:
Why does the destruction not reach the fourth dhyÄna?
Answer:
Because of the Pure Abodes.ğŸ”½Because those born in the highest stage attain parinirvÄá¹‡a there,
and do not descend to be born in lower stages, because of the non-analytical cessation of lower stages.
If they dwell in the realm destroyed by the kalpa, that is also not so, because they are born there by the power of superior blessings, and internal disturbance is not their share.
If there were disturbance internally in that realm, then externally there would be calamities.
In the first dhyana internally there is the disturbance of the fire of initial and sustained thought, so externally it is burned by the calamity of fire.
In the second dhyana internally there is the disturbance of the water of joy, so externally it is swept away by the calamity of water.
In the third dhyana internally there is the disturbance of the wind of inhalation and exhalation, so externally it is destroyed by the calamity of wind.
Question:
Since the fourth dhyana has never been disturbed, why does it not last forever?
Answer:
Because it is destroyed by momentary impermanence.
According to this explanation, the fourth dhyana realm is not continuous. The palaces arise together with the birth of the gods there. If the gods' lives end, they also disappear together.
Question:
Which kalpa ends first?
Answer:
After seven fires in succession, then one water calamity,
Seven times fire, seven times water, and then seven times fire, followed by wind.
As for the seven fires arising in succession, it refers to the first fire kalpa.
It is said that when the fire kalpa is about to arise, at that time the human lifespan is 80,000 years. Those who die in the hells will not be reborn again. One should know that the kalpa is ending.
Until there is not a single sentient being remaining in the hells, this is called the end of the kalpa of the hells.
Just as the kalpa of the hells ends, so it is for the animals and hungry ghosts.
If there are animals that are useful to humans, they end together with humans.
At that time, in JambudvÄ«pa there is only one person, without anyone to teach them, who can enter the first dhyÄna. Having arisen from the first dhyÄna, they raise their voice and proclaim:
The joy and bliss of separation is extremely pleasant!
In this way, the sound spreads and is passed on to each other, reaching all of JambudvÄ«pa.

Other sentient beings, without a teacher's instruction, all enter the first dhyÄna, and so on, until not a single sentient being remains in JambudvÄ«pa. This is called the end of the eon for JambudvÄ«pa.
Only except for Uttarakuru.
The same is true for all the good destinies in the desire realm.
Those in Uttarakuru who have ended their lives and have not attained dhyÄna cannot attain separation from desire.
Moreover, at that time, a sentient being in the first dhyÄna, without a teacher, enters the second dhyÄna. After rising from dhyÄna, they shout out, saying:
The joy and pleasure born from samÄdhi is extremely blissful!
Such sounds spread throughout the Brahma Heaven.
The same is true for the other sentient beings.
Until not a single sentient being remains in the first dhyÄna, this is called the end of the sentient beings' eon.
At that time, the world remains empty for a long time, until seven suns appear.
Question:
From where do they emerge?
Answer:
Some say that when the eon is formed, behind Mount Yugandhara, there are seven sun disks that reside there, and they emerge from there.
Some say that one day is divided into seven parts.
Some also say that one day is seven times hotter.
Some also say that it comes out from the fire of AvÄ«ci Hell.
Those who say this say that it arises from the world of the dominant fruit of the karma of sentient beings.
When that karma is exhausted, such disturbances arise, up to the burning of the Brahma Heaven.
Seven fires occur in succession, then one water disaster. After seven fire disasters have passed, then there is one water disaster, up to destroying the second dhyÄna heaven.
Question:
From where does the water arise?
Answer:
Some say that hot ash water rains from the edge of the third dhyÄna heaven.
Some also say that the water wheel surges forth.
Disturbances arise as explained before.
Seven sevens of fire, sevens of water. After seven fires occur in succession, then one water disaster. In this way, seven sevens of fire disasters and one seven of water disasters.
As for after seven fires, then wind, after seven fire disasters have passed, then one wind disaster occurs. Water disasters and wind disasters arise in sequence from fire disasters.
This is well said.
This is the lifespan of the Heaven of Universal Purity, sixty-four eons.
The water disaster floods up to the second dhyana heaven, the wind disaster destroys up to the third dhyana heaven, and the one billion four continents are destroyed at the same time.

For nineteen intermediate eons, the world is empty. For one intermediate eon, the world of vessels is destroyed. For one intermediate eon, the world of vessels is formed. For nineteen intermediate eons, it gradually abides in sequence.
If a place is first empty, that place will last until the end;
if a place is last empty, that place will abide first.
Question:
How does the mind become disturbed?
Answer:
Mistaken, confused, retribution for past karma, fear and injury,
If one's limbs and joints are severed, the sages say it is due to water, fire, and wind.

Those who are frightened and injured by the retribution of past karma, there are four causes of mental disturbance: disturbance of the four great elements, retribution of past karma, fear, and injury to the body.
Disturbance of the four great elements means that because of improper diet, the four great elements are disturbed, and because the four great elements are disturbed, it causes mental disturbance.
Retribution of past karma means that the karma of causing mental disturbance has already matured.
Question:
What is it?
Answer:
Favoring the transmission of misfortune, causing others to suffer.
Or scolding by saying:
You are foolish, crazy, and mentally disturbed.
Driving and forcing beings to fall into dangerous places, burning mountains and marshes, forcibly giving others alcohol, or speaking the Buddha's words upside down with deluded thoughts.
Such karma results in mental disturbance.
Fear means seeing non-human forms coming, being startled and frightened, and because of fear, the mind becomes disturbed.
Injury to the body means being beaten by non-humans.
Because they defile the great assembly, the Buddha, the Sangha, and the stÅ«pas, non-humans become angry and strike them, causing their minds to become disturbed.
This is said about ordinary people.
For sages, there is no retribution for past karma, and their minds are not disturbed.
If one has previously planted karma with fixed retribution, one will first experience the retribution and then transcend and be reborn in a higher realm.
If one has planted karma with undetermined retribution, if one transcends and is reborn in a higher realm, that karma will be extinguished.
Those with disturbed minds are in the desire realm. In the hells, there is no disturbance of the mind, because it is always disturbed.
In the animal realm, the ghost realm, and the human realm, there is disturbance of the mind, except in Uttarakuru.
In the heavens of the desire realm, there is also disturbance of the mind.
Question:
Whose minds are disturbed among the sages?
Answer:

SrotÄpannas, saká¹›dÄgÄmins, anÄgÄmins, arhats, and pratyekabuddhas - only the Buddha's mind is undisturbed, his voice is indestructible, his hair does not turn white, his face does not wrinkle, and he does not gradually enter parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The World-Honored One's agitated karma has long since ceased and ended, because he practices the wonderful practice.
Agitation refers to the mental consciousness, not the five consciousnesses, because they do not discriminate.
Agitation of the contaminated mind, not the uncontaminated, because of true practice.
Therefore, if it is said that mental agitation is distraction,
four alternatives are made.
The first alternative is the good contaminated mind and non-obscured-neutral mind of the agitated one.
The second alternative is the defiled mind of one abiding in one's own characteristics.
The third alternative is the defiled mind of the agitated one.
The fourth alternative is the good mind and non-obscured-neutral mind of one abiding in one's own characteristics.
Question:
What are the three great elements that can disjoin the limbs and joints?
Answer:
If it can disjoin the limbs and joints, the sages say water, fire, and wind.
The three great elements can disjoin the limbs and joints, not the earth element, because it is not beneficial.

As for the fire element loosening the joints, when one is about to die, the fire element increases and burns the tendons all over the body. After burning the tendons, the joints are loosened one by one. After the joints are loosened, one will die soon.
As for the water element loosening the joints, when the joints are loosened, it first causes the tendons to rot. After the tendons rot, the rest is as explained above.
As for the wind element loosening the joints, it causes the tendons to break. After the tendons break, the rest is as explained above.
After the joints are loosened, one will die within a day and night, because the four elements are in disorder.
Hell beings do not have loosened joints, because their joints are always loosened, and they do not die because of karmic retribution.
Animals, hungry ghosts, and the three directions have loosened joints, except for Uttarakuru, because they have no evil karma.
The gods are also like this.
Ordinary beings and noble ones have loosened joints, except for the Buddha.
Those with karmic retribution have loosened joints, because the Buddha has no karmic retribution.
The loosening of the joints has been explained. Now the regression will be explained.
There are three kinds of those who are liable to regress: those who have attained, those who have not attained, and those who practice.
Or one person regresses once, those who have not attained are said to regress twice,
That is, they regress in practice, and the three sages are also like this.
Those who are liable to regress are of three kinds: regression of attainment, regression of what has not been attained, and regression of practice.
Those who regress in attainment, when the merits they have attained encounter conditions for regression, they regress.
Those who regress in what has not been attained, the merits they should attain are not attained due to negligence.
Those who regress in practice, the merits they have attained are not practiced due to conditions.
Question:
What kind of person regresses in what way?
Answer:
Or one person regresses once.
If one regresses in attainment, one is a dull-faculty Å›rÄvaka, not a sharp-faculty one. Because one of sharp faculties has the power of samÄdhi, therefore it is said.
Or how do we know there is regression in attainment?
Answer:
Because two kinds of arhats are mentioned, namely those liable to regress and those not liable to regress.
If it is said that the path regresses but the fruit does not regress, that is not so.
Why is it so?
Because the attainment of elimination is united with the path. Attainment is included in the truth of the path. Therefore it is not so that the path regresses but not the elimination.

If it is said that if the seeds of afflictions are eliminated, how can they arise again, it should be said that just as the first pure mind arises without a prior cause, so it is with that [elimination].
Moreover, because there are causes and conditions for one's own part, afflictions arise from the causes and conditions for one's own part in beginningless birth and death.
It is not so that afflictions arise in the three realms as stated.
Why is it so?
Because the conditions for the arising of afflictions are fulfilled. It is said that sentient beings arise.
Afflictions have three causes and conditions, namely the power of causes, the power of objects, and the power of skillful means.

The proclivity of desire and love that has not yet been eliminated and known is the power of causes. One who has eliminated it is unobstructed. One who knows it is liberated. The dharmas that are attached to by the bonds of desire and love are the power of objects. Incorrect thought is the power of skillful means.
This is what he said.
If it is said that it arises from that, then incorrect thought would not arise if it is not a condition.
If there is incorrect thought before, then it would be endless.

Moreover, if good and neutral minds do not arise in the end, and if the continuum of incorrect thought is endless, then other thoughts would not be able to arise. If they do not arise, liberation would also not be a condition. The burning of afflictions should not arise again.
Just as fire burns wood to become ash, and in the end becomes ash and does not become wood again.
In the same way, an arhat burns the firewood of afflictions with the fire of wisdom, and should not become afflicted again.
They should not be like this.
Why is it so?
Because it is not like the example.
How is it like burning firewood and having ash?
If it is like this, does an arhat have remaining afflictions like ash?
If there are remaining afflictions, he is not an arhat, because he has afflictions.
If there are none, it is not like the above example.
However, it is not that the noble path burns away afflictions like fire burning firewood. It is only when the noble path arises that it severs afflictions and attains the attainment of liberation.
If one is separated from the noble path, one also abandons the attainment of liberation, and the attainment of bondage arises again.
As the sutras that contradict the stage of regression explain, one should know that it refers to the liberation that is not time-dependent.

As for the two types of regression from what has not yet been attained, if one regresses from what has not yet been attained, it refers to Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, not buddhas, because they abide in the most excellent faculties in all respects.

ÅšrÄvakas do not attain the superior faculties of buddhas and pratyekabuddhas, and pratyekabuddhas do not attain the superior faculties of buddhas. Therefore, there is regression from what has not yet been attained.

In brief, it is said that all sentient beings who cultivate should attain the wisdom eye of the noble ones. Those who do not cultivate and enter name-and-form are said to regress from what has not yet been attained.
Question:
How do we know there is regression from what has not yet been attained?
Answer:
Because of faith in the Buddha's teachings.
As the World-Honored One said:
The gods and worldly people who regress in wisdom, attached to name and form, do not see the truth.

As for those who regress in practice and the three sages are also thus, if one regresses in practice, it means that the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and tathÄgatas, the three sages, all have it, because of the various causes and conditions in the middle, the merits they have attained cannot always be present.
Question:
How do we know there is regression in practice?
Answer:
Because it is said that the mind and mental factors regress.
As the World-Honored One said:
Regarding these four kinds of mind and mental factors, attaining present-life bliss and abiding, I say they each regress.
As extensively explained in the sÅ«tras.
Moreover, it is also said that those who attain the immovable liberation of the mind and realize it with the body do not regress.
Therefore, we know that the World-Honored One also has regression in practice. Therefore, it is said.
The World-Honored One often abides in the preliminary stage, not in the fundamental stage.
Why is it so?
Because it is close to the desire realm.

Although the liberation of the immovable mind has the degeneration of practice, since they accomplish the cultivation of attainment, all of them always continue in the present time. The present cultivation of mind and mental factors refers to the degeneration of those not presently manifest.
The one with the most degeneration of practice is the World-Honored One.
Why is it so?
Because his merits are boundless.
It is like a wheel-turning sage king extensively receiving the realms.
It is also said that because he subsumes others, he is called immovable, and because he subsumes himself, he is called mind and mental factors.
The World-Honored One subsumes many others and few himself. Thus the World-Honored One's great compassion and great equanimity.
Question:
Where does one not regress?
Answer:
The gods do not regress, and those who regress in fruition will never die.
They also do not create that karma, which is not done by one abiding in fruition.
The gods do not regress means the gods do not regress, because gods with sharp faculties attain fruition. Those with sharp faculties do not regress.
If a person of dull faculties attains fruition but is later reborn in the heavens, he also does not retrogress, because there is no rebirth.
It has already been explained that sages do not retrogress without being reborn. Because the conditions for retrogressing are not applicable.
The World-Honored One has explained five conditions for retrogressing, such as having many activities, and so on.
Those heavens do not have the five dharmas for retrogressing. Therefore, they do not retrogress. Because the heavens do not retrogress,
one should know that those who retrogress must be among humans, because the conditions for retrogressing can be obtained there.
Those who retrogress from fruition do not die without attaining fruition again. Why is it so?
Because the non-analytical cessation of the lower realms does not cease forever, and the dharma of non-analytical cessation never appears again, because it is a dharma of non-arising.
Because the path included in fruition is definite and ultimately definite, and because the path of fruition is a place of rest, that person attains rest.
Moreover, because the place of fruition is well-protected, because the place of fruition is endowed with three causes and five causes, as explained before.

The three fruits can regress, but not the fruit of stream-entry. Because the afflictions eliminated by the path of seeing are not the objects of that [path of cultivation]. The afflictions eliminated by the path of seeing revolve around the self, but there is no self.ğŸ”½The afflictions eliminated by the path of cultivation are the objects of that [path of cultivation]. The afflictions eliminated by the path of cultivation revolve around purity, and there is the thought of purity regarding them.
Contemplating the impurity of conditioned phenomena, one attains the purity of detachment. One regresses from the view of impurity.
There is no thought of self or mine regarding phenomena. One regresses from the view of what is not a self as a self.
Moreover, the fruit of stream-entry is the extensive means of the past, such as giving, morality, and cultivation, directed towards liberation, and so on.

Furthermore, because the fruit of stream-entry is attained by the path of seeing, there is no regression from the path of seeing. Because it is the swift path, sharp, and the antidote to the peak of existence.

If one regresses from the fruit of arhatship to the fruit of stream-entry, one should know that one regresses from three fruits. Because one accomplishes the antidotes to the afflictions of those [fruits]. One also does not create the karma of those [fruits] as one who abides in the fruits does.
If it is not done by one who has attained the fruit, one who has fallen back from the fruit also does not do it.
Why is this?
Because one obtains the discipline of non-action, and because the holy path has already eliminated evil conduct, just like having taken medicine before.
Moreover, because one is endowed with hope, that person hopes to eliminate the fruit and counteract evil conduct.
Question:
Up to what point can one be said to be a bodhisattva?
Answer:
If one cultivates the various major and minor marks, and gives rise to the karma of skillful means,
From this point onwards, one is said to be a bodhisattva.
If there are sentient beings who, with a single meal, give rise to a determined mind and make a fearless statement:
I shall become a buddha.

If one is able to give rise to the retribution of marks and increase that karma, this is called a bodhisattva, because from this point onwards one is able to create karma that is similar and continuous.
If it is not like this, then it is just an empty name.

Although bodhisattvas may have an initial irreversible mind, this is not necessarily the case for bodhi. It should be said that they reach their destination, and are called determined together with those who have reached their destination.
That is to say, once they have created the karma that will result in their characteristics, they are both determined.
Therefore, they are named according to the karma that will result in their characteristics.
Because they are free from four conditions, namely, free from evil destinies, free from being non-male, free from low birth, and free from incomplete faculties.
They obtain one condition, namely, being born with the ability to recognize past lives.
Because they are born with the ability to recognize past lives, they immediately accept and uphold [the teachings].

Their retinue believes and accepts them, free from the faults of sentient beings, transcending three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, planting the karma that will result in their characteristics during a hundred kalpas, except for ÅšÄkyamuni.
Because ÅšÄkyamuni Bodhisattva was diligent, he eliminated nine kalpas, with the remaining ninety-one kalpas.
Some say two or three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas are not asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, namely, asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas of kalpas, asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas of births, and asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas of good conduct.
Question:
What is the nature of the karma that is to be reciprocated?
Answer:
It is bodily karma, verbal karma, and superior mental karma.
It is also the nature of thought and wisdom, not the wisdom of hearing.
Because it is inferior, it is not the wisdom of cultivation.
Because it is not fixed in the desire realm, it is cultivated in JambudvÄ«pa and not in other regions.

It is cultivated by men and not by women, when the Buddha appears in the world and not when he does not appear in the world, by those who see the Buddha and not by those who do not see the Buddha, and by those who take the Buddha as the object of their karma and not by those who take others as the object.
Some say that a single thought-wish produces the karma for the thirty-two marks, and later various karmas fulfill them.

Moreover, it is said that with a single mind, a single thought, and a single object, many thought-wishes appear before one, some wishing for the result of a flat and stable foundation, some wishing for the flesh-crown, and each of these marks has a retinue of a hundred merits.
As for the measure of merit, some say that the merit of a single wheel-turning sage king is called the measure of a single merit.
Moreover, it is said that it is the merit of a single Åšakra.
Some say that when the eon is formed, the power of the karma of all sentient beings gives rise to the world of the vessel. This is called the measure of merit.
Some say that except for bodhisattvas close to the stage of buddhahood, the merit, happiness, and mastery of karma of all other sentient beings is called the measure of one merit.
The Buddha's unlearned dharmas are bodhi, namely the knowledge of extinction and the knowledge of non-arising. The sattva seeks this knowledge, so it is called bodhi.
The sattva attains this bodhi and awakens to all dharmas, so it is called a buddha.
Although one is reborn as a wheel-turning sage king after the karma of the characteristics of the body, one should know that the characteristics of the sage king are the retribution of other karma.
Question:
How many kinds of SarvÄstivÄda are there?
Answer:
One kind of different discrimination, or some say the characteristics are different,
Or it is said that the parts are different, or it is said that they are different from each other.
As for these four kinds of SarvÄstivÄda, those who say that when dharmas change with the world, the parts are different but not the substance, are of one kind of different discrimination.

Just as milk changes into curd, abandoning taste, strength, and benefits but not abandoning color, or just as gold and silver vessels are broken and then made into other vessels, abandoning shape but not abandoning color.
The dharmas from the future to the present are also like this.
One should know that this is the transformation of the SarvÄstivÄdins.
As for the difference in characteristics, past dharmas are combined with past characteristics, not apart from future and present characteristics.
Just as a person is attached to one color but is not unattached to the others, it is the same for them.
This statement has a fault. If past dharmas are not apart from future and present characteristics, then what is accomplished in the end? It also accomplishes the meaning of combination.
If so, then the world would be in chaos.

Just as a person is attached to one color, being attached to one color, they both practice and accomplish, but they accomplish the others without practicing. Therefore their statement is that the world would be in chaos.
The analogy also contradicts.
As for the difference in parts, it is said that when dharmas change with the world, they differ in parts but not in substance.
This is not a confused establishment of time.
Why is it so?
Because of the difference in karma.
It is said that dharmas that have not yet performed karma are called future, those that are performing karma are called present, and those that have performed karma are called past.
As for their difference, they say that when dharmas change with time, they are in a state of mutual dependence before and after, not different in substance nor different in part.
Just as a single woman is called both a daughter and a mother, because of mutual dependence before and after.
It is said that observing a daughter one knows a mother, observing a mother one knows a daughter. This is the most confused establishment of time.

They say that in the past, present, and future there are three times in a single instant. It is said that observing the arising characteristics in the past is called future, observing the arising characteristics in the present is called present.
Now, I will explain the five branches as they are. The five branches are: 1. thesis, 2. reason, 3. example, 4. combination, 5. conclusion, and 6. meaning as stated in the verse below.
In sequence, without interval, etc., due to the different characteristics of knowledge and truth,
Seeing a pot but not seeing a garment, therefore it is also so.
The practitioner first contemplates suffering without interval, etc., and later up to the path.
Question:
Why is it so?
Answer:
Due to the different characteristics of knowledge and truth.
The knowledge of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path each have different characteristics, because their practices are separate.
If the practice is the knowledge of suffering, this practice is not the other knowledge.
If it were not so, there would be no establishment of the four knowledges.

The truths also have different characteristics. Oppression is the characteristic of suffering, arising is the characteristic of accumulation, cessation is the characteristic of cessation, and liberation is the characteristic of the path.
It is not that without different knowledge, different characteristics, and one truth, there is no interval, etc.
It is like when seeing a pot, one does not see a cloth, because the pot and cloth have different characteristics.
Because of their different characteristics, when seeing a pot one does not see a cloth, and when seeing a cloth one does not see a pot.
It is the same with this. When seeing suffering in the different characteristics of the truths, one does not see the others, and so on for all.
Therefore, there is no interval, etc.
As for saying there is one interval, etc., they say there is one interval, etc., in the truths.
Why is it so?
Because one believes in the sages and worthies.
As the World-Honored One said:
Bhiká¹£us, there is no doubt about suffering, no doubt about the accumulation, and no doubt about the cessation and path, either.
It is like a lamp simultaneously performing four functions: heating the vessel, burning the wick, exhausting the oil, and dispelling the darkness.
In the same way, one cognition knows suffering up to cultivating the path. Therefore, there is one interval, etc.
As for their saying that cognition and the truths have different characteristics, that is not so, because they have the same characteristic.
All wisdom has the characteristic of one cognition, and takes the realm of all dharmas as the practice of no-self.
As the World-Honored One said:
All dharmas are without self, this can be seen by the wise.
When one is disgusted with suffering, this is the purification of the path.
The characteristics of the truths are also explained in this way.
As for the different characteristics of pots and clothes, this is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because the specific characteristics are not continuous, etc.

The common characteristics are the objects of cognition, which are not the specific characteristics. The characteristics of impermanence are the characteristics of the destruction of the five aggregates such as form, etc.
The cognition of the common objects is one, without continuity, etc. If it were different, then one would create one's own faults.
As for the one who speaks of the continuity of the uninterrupted sequence,
you say that the sages speak of this, but this is a secret language, this is said to have a remaining meaning.
As the World-Honored One said:
If there is no doubt about suffering, then there is no doubt about anything.
It is said for those who doubt and practice.
If that suffering were to arise without continuity, etc., then that doubt would not be practiced to the end, because it is a non-numerically extinguished [dharma].
In order to eliminate the remaining [doubts], the World-Honored One said:
The Sutra of the Benefactor of the Solitary says like this:
Elder!
In the four noble truths, there is no interval, no equality,
and so on, explaining in detail.
As for what is said to be like a lamp, a lamp has many natures and many functions, I do not take the lamp as an example.
If it is analyzed, the lamp loses its own name, as explained before.
That light is included in the form sense base, able to destroy darkness, that heat is included in the touch sense base, able to do other things.
If it were not so, it would destroy the meaning of determination.
Wisdom is not like this, if it is said to be the same, then there is an error, if it is said to have one characteristic, this is also not so, because the functions are different.
The wisdom of impermanence is different, the wisdom of suffering, emptiness, no-self, and so on are also each different, like this and so on.
If it were not so, there would be no door to liberation.
The undestroyed function is the door to liberation, miscellaneous observation is called the destruction of the three liberations, because of different observations, it is undestroyed.
As you say, taking all dharmas as the object and cultivating the practice of non-self is because one suddenly contemplates all dharmas.
This is then not the definite contemplation of the aspects.

The definite contemplation of the practice is each separately taking the truths as the object. Therefore, one should not say that when one is disgusted with suffering, that is the purification of the path. One cannot take the practice of disgust as the object of cessation and the path, because cessation and the path are things that should be delighted in.
The universal object does not extend to all, because they are mutually contradictory.
Because the practice of non-self is not the same as the practice of this non-self, and the nature does not observe itself.
There is also no duality of definite nature, and it does not observe the same practice and the same object as associated dharmas, and it also does not observe the same result as co-existent dharmas.
Moreover, saying that all practices are impermanent is also not the practice of impermanence, because cessation is produced without interval, and cessation is permanent.
One should know that those practices are distant, because they are said to be directed towards the truth.
As it is said, contemplating this sentient being who has long cultivated evil actions of body, speech, and mind,
It is said that this sentient being is hell and other evil destinies, but in reality this person is not hell, because it is said that he is heading towards hell.
It is the same for him.
Moreover, if it is empty, without interval, etc., then it is not without wishes or characteristics, because all dharmas are not within its scope.
Do not say there is a fault, therefore the practice of no-self in all dharmas is an indeterminate contemplation.
The determinate contemplation is with outflows and objects, if it were not so, the doors of liberation would be diminished.
If it is said that the self-characteristics are without interval, etc., and not within the scope, it is not so.
Why is it so?
Because of contemplation.

The self-characteristics and common characteristics are the characteristic of oppression, which is the characteristic of suffering. Because of contemplating the three truths, it is the self-characteristics. Because of contemplating the aggregates, it is the common characteristics.
In this way, it should be known that all are said to be the self-characteristics and common characteristics because of contemplation.
The statement not so means it is not so.
Why is it so?
Because of the indestructible view, as explained before.
What was explained before will be explained later and is being explained now.
Question:
Is there an intermediate existence or not?
Answer:
It should be known that there is an intermediate existence, as taught by the World-Honored One,
Like between a village and a road, there are faults in both.
This explains the existence of an intermediate existence.
Why is it so?
Because it is taught by the World-Honored One.
As the World-Honored One said:
Among the seven destinies of beings, there is parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle.
If there were no intermediate existence, there would be no parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle.
If it is said that one who dies in the middle attains parinirvÄá¹‡a from there, it is not so, because it is not mentioned in the destiny of the gods.
The World-Honored One's sÅ«tras say:
From the Heaven of the Four Heavenly Kings up to the Sphere of Neither-Perception-Nor-Non-Perception, it is said that there is no premature death.
There are also faults in other [positions].
If it is said that one attains parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth, is there then a rebirth in the heavens?
In this way, all [the other types of non-returners] should be explained in the same way.
Therefore, this is a deluded explanation.

If it is said that one attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle of one's life, this is not so, except for those in Uttarakuru and the bodhisattvas in their last existence. There are many beings who die before their life span is exhausted. Do they all attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the middle?
Therefore, this is all faulty.
Question:
What is this like?
Answer:
It is like a road between villages.
Just as one goes from one village to another, so too does the intermediate existence go from the existence at death to the existence at birth. It is also like this.
As the AÅ›pÄrya-prajÃ±apti-Å›Ästra says:
If one comes from that place, it is explained in this way.
If there were no intermediate existence, there would be no going or coming. Therefore, there must be an intermediate existence.
If it is said that the sutra was taught to eliminate the remainder, the World-Honored One taught the sutra and verses as follows:
Having committed the five heinous crimes, one will be born in the AvÄ«ci Hell in succession.
Moreover, for the sake of the brÄhmaá¹‡a, he taught the verse:
Youth is carried away by old age and sickness, and one arrives before King Yama. For the brÄhmaá¹‡a, there is no place to stay, nor any provisions.
Therefore, the one without an intermediate state is not so.
Why is it so?

Because the path of karma is uninterrupted, the sutra and verse are taught, which means that having committed a heinous crime, one will definitely first receive the retribution of a heinous crime, and then receive the retribution of other karma, and will also definitely be born in the realm of hell, not in other realms.
As you understand, the World-Honored One taught the sutra that having committed the five heinous crimes, one will be born in hell in succession.
Is it necessary to be born in hell after committing the five heinous crimes?
Or is it two, three, or four?
Or is it that one is born in hell due to other crimes?
One should know the meaning of this sÅ«tra and verse.
If it is said that it is like a shadow, it is like the moon being extremely far away, and its reflection appears in the water, but the moon does not come to the water.
In the same way, the aggregates at death and the aggregates at birth are like a shadow. Why do sentient beings need an intermediate state? This is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because there is the fault of both being present.
The moon and the water are both present, but the aggregates at death and the aggregates at birth are not present together. Therefore, there is a fault.
The analogy of the eye consciousness and the body consciousness below is also like this.
If one first takes the aggregates at birth and abandons the aggregates at death, like the worm that sheds its tower, it is not so.
Why is it so?
Because there is the fault of the realms being different and the two consciousnesses combining.
Therefore, it is said that there is an intermediate state, as explained in the four types of SarvÃ¢stivÄda.
Question:
Are all existences, or are they non-existent?
Answer:
It should be known that all existences are not all existent,
All do not have all, there are no dharmas with other characteristics.
This exists, it is established by the SarvÄstivÄdins.
All refers to the twelve sense bases.
Those sense bases have their own characteristics, not the characteristics of others, because they are produced separately by all characteristics.
The difference in function has already been explained above.

All do not have all means that in conditioned dharmas there are conditioned dharmas, but not unconditioned dharmas, and in unconditioned dharmas there are unconditioned dharmas, but not conditioned dharmas.
Just as in space there are also no traces, it is like this and so forth.
Question:
This is said to exist, how is it that there is no?
Answer:
There are no dharmas with other characteristics.
Just as the characteristic of the eye is the sense base of the eye, it does not have the characteristics of other sense bases, because the characteristics are different.
For this reason, all dharmas are said to be unmixed.
All worlds have, without contradicting what is appropriate,
What is spoken by the Sage, the Saá¹…gha of hearers has no Buddha.
There is a SarvÄstivÄda of the three times, established by this SarvÄstivÄda.
Question:
Why is it so?
Answer:
The present time is established by observing the past and future. If there were no past and future, there would be no present time.
If there is no present time, there are also no conditioned dharmas. Therefore, there are three times.
Do not say there is fault.
If it is said that what is distant is the past, and what will be is the future, and that there is only the present, this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because there is karmic retribution.
The World-Honored One said:
There is karma and there is retribution.
It is not that karma and retribution exist in the present.ğŸ”½If karma is in the present, one should know that retribution is in the future.
If retribution is in the present, one should know that karma has already passed.ğŸ”½If it is said that worldly conventions speak of the doer as unobtainable,
if it is said that worldly conventions speak of karma and retribution, this is also not so.
The World-Honored One also says that the doer cannot be found.
Is this also a conventional expression?
The sutra spoken by the mouth of the spirit is the ultimate emptiness, but you use imagination to say that because this exists, that exists, and so on.
You should know that if you say that the distant past is the past and the future existence is the future, and only the present exists, do not say this.
I can also say that the present is the future in the past and the past in the future.
This is not what the wise say.
As it is said, if there is no faith and the other five faculties, I say they are ordinary people.
If a learner is bound by afflictions, the five faculties such as faith do not appear, because the path and afflictions do not coexist.
Therefore, you should know that there is past and future.
If it were different, the sage would be an ordinary person.
If it is said that they arise according to attainment, this is also not so.
Because there is no attainment of what is not a part.
Because it is not a part of the basis.
The Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas does not include the Buddha.
Why is it so?
Because the Three Jewels are not diminished.
If the World-Honored One were included in the Å›rÄvakas, there would be Three Jewels but not Three Buddhas, because there would be no separate essence.
Taking refuge and indestructible faith and mindfulness are also like this.
Do not say there is a fault, therefore the Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas does not include the Buddha.
As the World-Honored One's sÅ«tras say:
GautamÄ«!
Giving to the Saá¹…gha is also making offerings to me.

One should know that this refers to the Saá¹…gha of bhiká¹£us, the Saá¹…gha of sages, and the Saá¹…gha of fields of merit. The World-Honored One is included in those three saá¹…ghas, because he has destroyed afflictions, is a sage, and is the supreme field of merit, but not because the Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas is self-awakened.
Even if one were to elaborate on the scriptures, sentient beings would be greatly terrified,
Without the characteristics of supremacy and profundity, I will now explain only briefly.
If explained in detail, sentient beings would be frightened, therefore I will not explain it in detail now.
The profound phrases are well understood, and the clear wisdom that understands Abhidharma, the wonderful meaning of the scriptures, is briefly explained here.
The great teachers of the past have expounded immeasurable meanings,
I will now explain a small part according to my understanding.

I will now use a little wisdom to contemplate, compile, and compose phrases in the teachings of Venerable DharmatrÄta, in order to promote and assist in proclaiming the remaining teachings, not out of arrogance or seeking fame.
As he said, if afflictions arise, the sages say so.
The path of cessation of defilements also gives rise to afflictions, but it does not increase defilements, because afflictions are not a part of it.
The afflictions that take the undefiled as their object cease but do not increase, as explained before.
Therefore I say it increases.
It is not so that the soft, medium, and superior afflictions that take the undefiled as their object do not increase, because they increase based on it.
Definitely knowing the subtle meaning of the verses of this treatise,
Among the wise, one is courageous and fearless.

One who can definitely know and skillfully explain the meaning of the verses of this treatise will have no fear in the minds of the wise, because one skillfully understands the characteristics of dharmas.
I now increase the treatise, my mind is without greed,
In order to make the wise delight, and quickly attain the bliss of cessation.
The sÅ«tras are concise, but the meaning is profound and vast, difficult to accept and uphold.
Like the treatise on space, it is difficult to understand, as explained before.
Therefore, I increase the treatise, in accordance with the meaning of the sÅ«tras, making it easy to understand.
By understanding the meaning, afflictions are then eliminated.
The chapter on discernment has been explained. Now I will briefly explain the various treatises, to delight the wise.
Apart from discipline and undiscipline, one can obtain discipline,
And not because of them attain excellence?
Please explain decisively.
Answer:
There is.
It refers to when one falls from the formless realm and is reborn in the form realm.
Ordinary beings in the formless realm are called neither disciplined nor undisciplined, because good and evil disciplines in the formless realm are not applicable.
When they die in that realm and are reborn in the form realm, they obtain good discipline, because discipline in the form realm accompanies the mind.
It is not due to advancement, because the realm of the formless realm is superior.
Can one obtain the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, the holy ones free from faults,
And obtain conditioned good dharmas, but not be called a practitioner?
Answer:
There is.
It refers to when the holy path included in the fruits has ceased, and then one regresses but does not advance the faculties and regains them.
Because the path previously included in the past fruits has already ceased, it is not cultivated. Because the present cause is not applicable,
Free from faults means not worldly.
The conditioned is not the unconditioned.
The wholesome is not the unwholesome or indeterminate.
Before the path arises, it is far removed from all faults,
Is liberation when one is free from evil?
Please explain decisively.
Answer:
There is.
Namely, when a practitioner abides in the vajra samÄdhi, all other unlearned dharmas except for the initial knowledge of exhaustion are not yet arisen and do not move towards it.
As for the time of liberation, all unlearned paths are suddenly liberated.
When the initial knowledge of exhaustion arises, it is the time of arising, and it is the time of liberation.
As for being free from all faults and evils, it is because it is not contaminated.
Can one give rise to the entanglements of the Ä€bhÄsvara heaven, which are associated with that samÄdhi,
And retrogress from the pure first dhyÄna, while attaining the dharmas of retrogressing?
Answer:
There is.
Namely, when an arhat retrogresses from the entanglements of the second dhyÄna, the first dhyÄna attained through the knowledge of exhaustion retrogresses together with the knowledge of exhaustion.
Moreover, the cultivation of retreat is combined with the first dhyÄna and the fourth dhyÄna.
The same is true for the anÄgÄmin.
Pure clarifies what is retreated, because it is not without learning.
Can one attain those wholesome dharmas in the path of seeing the truths,
and are those dharmas with conditions, but the noble wisdom does not see the conditions?
Answer:
There are.

Namely, the knowledge of the desire realm and so forth that accompanies inferential knowledge of suffering. Even though it is cultivated in the immediate aftermath of suffering, it also does not see the conditions of that knowledge, because it takes the desire realm as its object, while inferential knowledge of suffering does not take the desire realm as its object.
The same is true for the immediate aftermath of the knowledge of origination and cessation.
The knowledge of the three truths attained by the receptivity to the knowledge of the path does not contemplate those truths, because it abides in a different realm.
Just as one who abides in the dharmas of learning attains the dharmas of no-more-learning, but the attainment of the dharmas of no-more-learning is not the dharmas of learning.
In the same way, from the class of knowledge of dharmas up to the class of inferential knowledge, the class of inferential knowledge again up to the class of knowledge of dharmas.
Can there be a result that is cut off by contaminated wisdom and uncontaminated wisdom,
Is it the case that the cause of that fruit arises, namely the wisdom free from desire?
Answer:
There is.
It refers to the noble ones who are free from desire in the desire realm but have not yet become free from desire in the first dhyÄna.
The mind of transformation that is the fruit of the desire realm and the first dhyÄna is free from desire, because the craving of the desire realm has ended.
The wisdom of the first dhyÄna is not yet free from desire, because that craving has not yet ended.
All minds of transformation are also like this. According to their meaning, one should eliminate the fruit of their own stage.
Is it the case that while abiding in the unhindered path, one attains the cessation of all [defilements],
And that the defilements that are incompatible with this [unhindered path] are not the objects of the undefiled view?
Answer:
There is.

It refers to when an ordinary person cultivates spiritual powers, the unhindered path eliminates the defilements that are incompatible with spiritual powers and attains the cessation of all [defilements], but they are not the objects of the undefiled view.
Why is this?
When the noble ones are free from desire, the dharma-patience is present, and they attain the cessation of the defilements that are incompatible with patience.
Is it the case that the cessation of all defilements is attained by one who is free from desire,
How can one not cut off afflictions and yet attain the exhaustion of defilements?
Answer:
There is.

It refers to when one ends one's life in a higher realm and is born in the Brahma heaven, one attains the cessation of desire realm afflictions, but does not cut off those afflictions, because they have already been cut off previously.
The same is true for all other realms.
Are there any pure realms that have never been attained and are attained,
not through detachment or regression, and not based on the path of seeing?
Answer:
There are.

It refers to when one detaches from desire for the first dhyÄna, and based on the first dhyÄna and its retinue, one gives rise to the knowledge of subsequent cognition of the path of supernormal birth, and accomplishes the fruit of non-returner of the three realms.
Rising from that concentration, one enters the second dhyÄna and attains the impurity of the second dhyÄna.
When one attains that impurity, it is not through detachment, because one has already detached previously.
It is not through regression, because it is an enhancement.
It is not the path of seeing, because the path of seeing is ultimate.
One should know that the same is true for the higher realms and the enhancement of faculties.
Have you attained the previously unattained, and attained tranquility,
without abandoning that which has not been attained?
If you know, please speak.
Answer:
There is.
It refers to the attainment of the path of the remaining uncontaminated dharmas, excluding the attainment of the retinue of the receptivity to the knowledge of the dharma with regard to suffering.
That first uncontaminated [attainment] abandons all the nature of ordinary beings, but does not attain [it].
The remaining [attainments] are not abandoned, because they have already been abandoned.
If one accomplishes the eight receptivities, one also accomplishes the seven knowledges.
These uncontaminated views do not see which uncontaminated [dharmas]?
Answer:
There are.

It refers to this person abiding in the receptivity to the knowledge of the path, accomplishing all the wisdom of the path of seeing, seeing all cessation and all paths, only excluding the retinue of the receptivity to the knowledge of the path.

That receptivity does not see its own nature, because it does not observe itself, and because there is no second nature. It also does not see what is associated, because there is one practice and one object.
It does not see what is coexistent, because there is one fruit and one determination.
Is there a dharma that has never been obtained, with contaminated objects,
Only the immovable one, can it strike good dharmas?
Answer:
There is.
Namely, the signless of the signless, which has never been obtained in endless birth and death, but obtains the holy path of emptiness, therefore it is said to have contaminated objects.
Because it is a non-analytical cessation, it is said to have objects on the periphery.
Because the rest are not included, it is said to be only immovable.
Because of the holy path of emptiness, it is said to strike good dharmas.
Having already given rise to uncontaminated wisdom, for those who have not yet given rise to it,
Are the former births not the cause of the latter?
If one can know, please speak.
Answer:
There is.
Namely, the former increase is not the cause of the latter softness, because their fruits are similar and increased.
Can one who has separated from the desire of the six stages, and is also a holy one who has attained their fruits,
Not attain uncontaminated meditation?
If one can know, please speak.
Answer:
There is.

It means that when one is free from desire for the sphere of infinite space, relying on the preliminary stage of the fourth dhyana, the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering arises, and the inferential knowledge of the path has not yet arisen. Because of the eighty-nine fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, it is said that one attains those fruits.

Because the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering is the fruit of the receptivity to the knowledge of dharmas with regard to suffering and the fruit of effort, and the exhaustion of the afflictions to be eliminated by seeing suffering is the fruit of liberation and the fruit of effort, but one does not attain the pure dhyÄnas, because they have not yet been attained.
Are there any pure dharmas that are included in the realms,
but the dharmas that can give rise to them do not enter into those realms?
Answer:
There are.
It means that the pure precepts are included in those realms, but are not included in the outflows.
Because the precepts are created by the four great elements, they are their fruit.
The four great elements are included in the sphere of touch, because they are the objects of the body consciousness.
Can it be that when one great element ceases, it does not arise in the stage of dhyÄna,
but two great elements are present beforehand?
If one can know this, please speak.
Answer:
There are.
It means that when an arhat is born in the desire realm, the impure first dhyÄna appears in succession to the pure first dhyÄna.

One kind of four great elements ceases, referring to the four great elements of the desire realm, which are pure and transforming. If they appear in the present in that realm, they are created by the four great elements of that realm.

Two kinds of four great elements appear in the present. It means that the four great elements of the desire realm and the first dhyÄna realm are called the pure and transforming precepts of the four paths. If one is born in the desire realm, they are created by the four great elements of the desire realm, so these four great elements arise and cease together with the pure [precepts].ğŸ”½Is there a dharma that is the cause of the three paths,
and has the nature of these three kinds,
and also exists in the three realms of the three kinds?
Answer:
There is.

It is the wisdom of the adept, which takes the path of insight, the path of cultivation, and the path of no-training as its cause. The knowledge of exhaustion, the knowledge of non-arising, and the views of the adept are its intrinsic nature. It is said to be of three kinds because of the distinctions of weak, medium, and strong. It is said to be of one stage because it is included in the stage of the adept. It is in three stages because of the distinctions of having initial and sustained thought, etc.
Is there any contaminated feeling that two are accomplished and one is not accomplished,
and two faculties and two kinds are accomplished, which is said to be the body witness?
Answer:
There is.

It refers to the person who has attained the body witness, who relies on the first dhyÄna, the retinue of the first dhyÄna, and the second dhyÄna to progress in faculties. The upper stages do not appear before him. He accomplishes the faculty of suffering and the contaminated faculty of pleasure.

This person previously attained the uncontaminated pleasure of the stage of the third dhyÄna, but because of changing faculties he abandoned it and has not yet attained it again. Because he relies on the lower stages to progress in faculties, he does not cultivate the path of training in the upper stages.
Just as when attaining the fruit of training, the faculty of sorrow is not accomplished because of being free from desire.
The faculty of joy and the faculty of equanimity each have two kinds, namely, contaminated and uncontaminated, and he fully possesses them.
Because the intermediate state of the preliminary stage of dhyÄna includes the faculty of equanimity, therefore he obtains the faculty of equanimity.
The first and second dhyÄnas include the faculty of joy, therefore he obtains the faculty of joy.
When the afflictions of the nine stages are extinguished, one attains the various dhyÄnas,
but one does not obtain the formless concentrations. Or perhaps one obtains them? This will be explained later.
The answer is:
There are.
That is to say, an arhat can obtain dhyÄna concentration but not the formless [concentrations]. The various dhyÄnas are both obtained and manifested.
As for the formless [concentrations], he accomplishes them but does not practice them.
One dharma has many natures, or one has three, existence and non-existence,
Are they the dharmas of the post-learner? Are they nourished by the power of causes?
The answer is:
There are.
That is to say, the faculty of non-knowing.
Because one faculty is established, it is said to be one.
Because of the combination of nine faculties, it is said to have many natures. Because of having many natures, it is said to be not one.
Therefore, it is said to be one ground. Because of the distinctions of initial and sustained thought, it is said to be three grounds.
Existence means having a name, non-existence means having no separate substance.
Because of attaining the stage of no-more-learning, it is said to be dharmas of no-more-learning. Because of being accomplished by three causes, it is said to be causes that nourish.
Are there any dharmas that are with parts, and with the other parts,
similarly arise, abide, and perish?
If one can know, please explain.
Answer:
There are.
Namely, the form sense-field is with the other parts. Their characteristics and the sense-field arise, abide, and perish together, because they have the same effect.

Because the form sense-field does not perform actions, it is said to be with the other parts. Because their characteristics are included in the dharma sense-field, they are with parts.ğŸ”½Are there any associated dharmas,
which are sometimes said to be with the other parts,
or are sometimes said to be with parts?
If one can know, please explain.
Answer:
There are.
Namely, the mental sense-field of future non-arising dharmas is with the other parts, because it does not perform actions.
The remaining mental factors are partially homogeneous, because they are included in the dharma-Äyatana.
Can two anÄgÄmins be born together in one place,
and both attain the fruit of one stage in the first dharma?
Answer:
There are.
Namely, one anÄgÄmin relies on the second dhyÄna to transcend birth, and the second anÄgÄmin relies on the third dhyÄna. When they end their life, they are both born in the third dhyÄna.
For the one who relies on the second dhyÄna to transcend birth, it is because of the advancement of dhyÄna.
The worldly first dharma is abandoned, and then relying on the third dhyÄna, it is accomplished and not abandoned.
The same is true for the higher stages.
Attaining the fruit of one stage means the dhyÄna without initial or sustained thought.
Can an akopya-dharma person experience one existence together,
and accomplish the wholesome with outflows of one stage and one without?
Answer:
There are.
Namely, one is born in the desire realm and one is born in the first dhyÄna.
Those born in the desire realm attain the contaminated dharmas of the nine stages.
